ionic.title: Ionic Compounds
ionic.body:
Ionic compounds

Name the cation first, then the anion. Main-group metals keep their charge; transition metals use Roman numerals.

  • NaCl: sodium chloride
  • FeCl2: iron(II) chloride

covalent.title: Molecular (Covalent) Compounds
covalent.body:
Molecular compounds

Use prefixes (mono-, di-, tri-, tetra-, etc.). The second element ends with -ide.

  • CO: carbon monoxide
  • CO2: carbon dioxide

acids.title: Acids
acids.body:
Acids

Aqueous binary acids use hydro- + root + -ic acid. Oxyacids use -ate/-ite to -ic/-ous.

  • HCl(aq): hydrochloric acid
  • HNO3(aq): nitric acid

polyatomic.title: Polyatomic Ions
polyatomic.body:
Polyatomic ions

Keep the polyatomic ion name. Examples include sulfate (SO4^2-), nitrate (NO3^-), ammonium (NH4^+).

hydrates.title: Hydrates
hydrates.body:
Hydrates

Name the salt + prefix-hydrate.

  • CuSO4Â·5H2O: copper(II) sulfate pentahydrate

roman.title: Roman Numerals
roman.body:
Roman numerals

For variable-charge metals, indicate the charge in parentheses.

  • FeO: iron(II) oxide
  • Fe2O3: iron(III) oxide

phases.title: Phases
phases.body:
Phases

Phase labels like (s), (l), (g), (aq) can change names. Example: HCl(aq) is hydrochloric acid, while HCl(g) is hydrogen chloride.
